OBITUARY:
Michael Joy Carter, a cherished pillar of his community and a beacon of love
and generosity, was called to his eternal home on October 16, 2025, in Rapid
City, South Dakota. Born on October 11, 1952, in Fostoria, Ohio, Mike lived a
life characterized by unwavering faith, an entrepreneurial spirit, and a deep
devotion to his family and friends.
Raised in the town of his birth, Mike graduated from Fostoria High School,
where he laid the foundation of hard work and integrity that would define his
personal and professional life. His commitment to these virtues was evident to
all who had the pleasure of knowing him. After decades of dedicated service
in his career, Mike embraced his passion for numismatics by opening Mike's
Coins in his retirement years. His coin shop quickly became more than a
business: it was a gathering place for those who shared his enthusiasm and a
testament to his belief in the value of community and fellowship.
Mike's life was a living example of his Christian faith, and his actions spoke
the love and teachings of Christ. As it is written, "Whatever you do, work
heartily, as for the Lord and not for men," (Colossians 3:23), Mike embodied
this scripture through his sincere approach to life and business. He treated
everyone he encountered with a level of kindness and respect that left a
lasting impression.
His family was the cornerstone of his existence. He is survived by his
daughter, Joy Sheffer, and her family, Kendra, Shae, Garrett, and Dalton; his
son, Mike "Joe", and his children, Emily, Erica, Michael, and Mitchell. His legacy of
love also lives on through his sister Pam Myers and her daughter Tammy; his
sister Brenda Cipiti and her husband Jeff; his brother Kevin Carter and Kevin’s
son KC; and his sister-in-law Debbie Carter, wife of his late brother Steve.
Mike was preceded in death by his parents, Donald and Josephine Carter, his
sister Lori Carter, and his brother Steve Carter.
Mike's love for the great outdoors was evident in his joy of riding his scooter
through the Badlands National Park, where he felt a deep connection with
God's creation. His interest in rare coins was not only a hobby but a shared
journey with fellow enthusiasts, as he guided many in the discovery and
appreciation of these historical treasures.

Those who knew Mike would describe him as loving, generous, and
thoughtful—a man who never missed an opportunity to help others or offer a
kind word. His legacy is not only in the coins he cherished but in the
immeasurable value of the relationships he nurtured.
As we honor the life of Michael Joy Carter, we are reminded of the words of
Mahatma Gandhi, "The best way to find yourself is to lose yourself in the
service of others;" Mike found himself through his service and love for his
family, friends, and community. His memory will be treasured, and his light will
continue to shine in the hearts of those who loved him.
A celebration of life will be scheduled at a later date. In lieu of flowers, the
family requests donations be made to Mike's Coins, 406 Cedar Street Apt
301, Monticello, MN 55362 to benefit the local youth.

Kerry Dean Daly, a man of indomitable spirit and boundless love, passed away peacefully due to cancer on October 19, 2025, in Lead, South Dakota. Born in Brookings, South Dakota, Kerry's life was a testament to the power of dedication, humor, and generosity. He lived a life rich with experiences and filled with the warmth of his family and friends.

Kerry's early years were spent in the halls of Cabrillo High School in Lompoc, California, where he laid the foundation for his future endeavors. His passion for craftsmanship led him to pursue and complete his education at a welding school in Tulsa, Oklahoma. This skill would later become the cornerstone of his professional life.

After a brief stint as a fisherman in Port San Luis, California, Kerry demonstrated his entrepreneurial spirit by establishing and running two very successful businesses: Yosemite Crane in Oakhurst, California, and Environmental Services in Las Vegas, Nevada. His later years were devoted to the Oil Field Services sector, where he contributed his expertise to companies such as Melgard, MMI, 3C, Circle C, and 325.

Kerry's zest for life extended beyond his professional achievements. He was an avid racer in the Blown Alcohol Hydroclass IHBA, where he channeled his competitive drive. Known as ""Goodnight"" in the boxing ring, Kerry boasted an impressive record of 13-0, with each victory coming by way of a first-round knockout. His love for sports was matched only by his love for spending quality time with his beloved family and friends.

A spiritual man, Kerry believed in the interconnectedness of life and the universe. His faith was personal and profound, guiding him through the joys and challenges of his journey. He was a beacon of love and laughter, always ready to share a generous smile or a hearty chuckle.

Kerry is survived by his devoted wife, Tiffany Daly; his step-daughter, Mekel Ross, and her husband, Chris; his cherished granddaughter, Sydnee Burrell; and his adored grandsons, Kaynen and Holland Burrell. His loving mother, Jane Daly; his brother, Steve Daly, and his wife, Denise; his sister, Paula Daly; his niece, Jessica Rainey, and her husband, Josh; and his great-nieces, Jolie and Jemma Rainey, will also hold his memory dear. Kerry was preceded in death by his father, Richard Daly, and his loyal animal companions, Damien and Billy.

""Life is not measured by the number of breaths we take, but by the moments that take our breath away,"" a quote often attributed to Maya Angelou, beautifully encapsulates Kerry's philosophy. He lived a life that took our breath away with its profound simplicity and depth of feeling.

Kerry Dean Daly will be remembered as a loving husband, a caring family man, a generous friend, and a man who brought laughter and light to all who had the pleasure of knowing him. His legacy of love, laughter, and generosity will continue to inspire those left behind, as they cherish the countless joyous moments he gifted to the world.

Upon his request cremation has taken place and a celebration of life will be held in the summer of 2026.

Kelly Lea Denny, aged 65, passed away peacefully of natural causes on November 3, 2025, in Rapid City, South Dakota. Born on November 30, 1960, in Minneapolis, Minnesota, Kelly's life was a tapestry of kindness, creativity, and an indomitable spirit that touched everyone she knew.

A graduate of Minneapolis Community College, Kelly dedicated her working years to serving others with a warm smile as a waitress in various restaurants. Her work ethic and the genuine connections she made with people were emblematic of her caring nature. She approached her work with the same passion she gave to every aspect of her life.

Kelly is survived by her longtime partner, Mark Bergstein, who shared with her a life filled with love and laughter. She also leaves behind her brothers, Joe, Tim, and Lawrence. Kelly was preceded in death by her parents, Jim Denny and Vivian Baker, as well as her brother Michael Baker. Her extended family will forever cherish the memories of her compassionate and creative soul.

Beyond her work, Kelly was an avid reader and an artist at heart. She expressed her creativity through various media, crafting a home that reflected her artistic vision. Her love for making art was only rivaled by her love for animals. Kelly's gentle heart extended to all creatures, and she ensured that every animal she met felt her kindness.

Those who knew Kelly will remember her as the epitome of kindness—a person who brought light into the lives of others. Her creative spirit will continue to inspire those who were fortunate enough to witness it. As an individual who always saw the beauty in the world, Kelly lived by the words of Vincent van Gogh, "I am seeking, I am striving, I am in it with all my heart." Her passionate pursuit of life's joys was evident to all who knew her.

As we say goodbye to Kelly Lea Denny, we celebrate a life well-lived, a journey filled with love, art, and the warmth of an ever-giving heart. Her spirit will forever be a beacon of light to those she has left behind. Kelly's legacy of kindness and creativity will live on in the memories of her family, friends, and all who were graced by her presence. May she rest in peace, knowing that her life was a masterpiece of her own making.

Upon her request cremation has taken place and no services are planned at this time.

Jeffrey Michael Daley age 49 years passed away at his home on Saturday April 27th.

He was born at the West River Medical Center in Hettinger, ND. July 19th, 1974 to Audrey Gaaskjolen and Gary Daley. As a baby and small child, Jeffrey lived on his grandma and grandpa Gaaskjolen's ranch. Then moved with his family to several different locations. He went to grade school in Lemmon,SD the first years. He then moved with Audrey and new dad Tim Lorius, to Dickinson ND, where additional grades were completed. From there he moved to Rapid City, SD with his mom and step dad. He finished grade school and started school at Sturgis Brown High School. Jeff graduated from high school and pursued a degree in mechanics at Western Dakota Technical College in Rapid City. He worked for Al's D & I until the day of his passing. Jeff was a wonderful, kind, caring man who used his hands to make a living. There were many cars fixed and restored with those hard working hands. Jeff married the love of his life Kristen Dansby on November 3rd, 2007. Jeff and Kirsten were together for 21 years, married for 17 years. He had three step children, Isaiah, Kayanna and Annabel. As their love for each other grew, so did their family with the addition of Aubriel who was born December 25th, 2013.  Every summer he helped his grandpa Marlin on the ranch when he could get away. Jeff and grandpa Marlin spent many hours working on vehicles and equipment together in the shop. He loved the ranch and it will be his final resting place. He loved visiting his grandpa and grandma Daley on their ranch and getting to see all of his cousins, aunts and uncles. Jeff had a great love for vehicles and one of his favorites was a '66 Chevrolet pickup he bought from grandpa Marlin with his hard earned money. He fixed it up and was very proud of it. He was a perfectionist in everything he did. and succeeded in everything he wished to accomplish. Throughout Jeff’s entire life he loved to fish and caught some really big ones. Some of the passions he had included hiking, camping and fishing and created many treasured memories with his family on these trips. He loved working on cars and was an excellent mechanic. The hard worker that he was, he remodeled his house with the help of A J Mindt, his friend. His yard was always immaculate, putting in his own sprinkler system. There wasn't much Jeff couldn't do, once he set his mind to it. While remaining dedicated to family, life and work Jeff always thought highly of his brother, Shiloh and they were always there for each other. Blessed to have shared his life are his wife, Kirsten; four children, Isaiah, Kayanna, Annabel and spunky little Aubriel, Jeff's father-in-law, Walter Dansby, Jr and two sister-in-laws, Jenny and Baylee and four brother-in-laws, Walter III, Xavier, Jaedn and Gavyn; his mother, Audrey (Tim); brother, Shiloh (Andrea); Father, Gary Daley and good friend, AJ Mindt; favorite aunt, Dianne Daley-Hellekson and cousin, Amy Daley and many numerous other relatives and friends.  

Jeff Daley was preceded in death by grandparents Marlin and Dora Lee Gaaskjolen of Meadow and James and Marie Daley of Thunderhawk, SD.

RIP Jeff you are so greatly loved and missed.

 

Memorial Service will be at the Lorius Ranch near Meadow, SD. June 23rd, 2024 at 2pm. Friends and family are all invited.
